column1: The name "Kuching" was already in use for the city by the time Brooke arrived in 1841. There are many theories as to the derivation of the name "Kuching". It was perhaps derived from the Malay word for cat
column2: "kucing" or from Cochin
column3: an Indian trading port on the Malabar Coast and a generic term in China and British India for trading harbour. Some Hindu artefacts can be seen today at the Sarawak State Museum. However
column4: another source reported that the Kuching city was previously known as "Sarawak" before Brooke arrived. The settlement was renamed to "Sarawak proper" during the kingdom expansion. It was only in 1872 that Charles Brooke renamed the settlement to "Kuching".There was one unlikely theory based on a story on miscommunication. According to the story
column5: James Brooke arrived in Kuching on his yacht Royalist. He then asked his local guide about the name of the town. The local guide mistakenly thought that Brooke was pointing towards a cat
column6: and so had said the word "Kuching". However
column7: ethnic Malays in Sarawak have always used the term "pusak" for cats (cognate with Filipino pusa)
column8: instead of the standard Malay word "kucing". Despite this etymological discrepancy
column9: Sarawakians have adopted the animal as a symbol of their city.

column1: Some source also stated that it was derived from a fruit called "mata kucing" (Euphoria malaiense)
column2: a fruit that grows widely in Malaysia and Indonesia. There was also a hill in the city that was named after the fruit
column3: which is called Bukit Mata Kuching. A British woman writing to her son in the 19th century
column4: stated that the name was derived from a stream of the same name
column5: called "Sungai Kuching" or Cat River in English. On page 64 of Bampfylde and Baring-Gould's 1909 'A History of Sarawak under its Two White Rajahs'
column8: is so called from a small stream that runs through the town into the main river...." The stream was situated at the foot of Bukit Mata Kuching and in front of the Tua Pek Kong Temple. In the 1950s
column9: the river became very shallow because of silt deposits in the river. The river was later filled to make way for roads.There is another theory that Kuching actually means "Ku" (古）- Old and "Ching"（井） - Well or "old well" (古井) in Chinese. During the Brooke administration
column10: there was no water supply and water-borne diseases were common. In 1888
column11: an epidemic broke out which later was known as "Great Cholera Epidemic". A well situated in the present day China Street in Main Bazaar helped to combat the disease by providing clean water supply. Due to increased demand for a water supply
column12: the role of the well was later replaced by water treatment plant on the Bau Road.

column2: Kuching plays an important role in the political and economic welfare of the population of the entire state as it became the seat of the state government where almost all of their ministries and agencies are based. The Sarawak State Legislative Assembly is located at the suburb of Kuching in Petra Jaya.

column1: There are 5 Members of Parliament (MPs) representing the five parliamentary constituencies and twelve  state legisative assemblyman in the state legislature representing twelve state constituencies in Kuching district.
Kuching is the only city in Malaysia to be administered by two mayors
column2: the city is divided into Kuching North and Kuching South. Each of these is administered by a mayor for Kuching South and commissioner for Kuching North. The current commissioner for Kuching North is Datuk Abang Wahap Abang Julai

column1: Kuching is located on the banks of the Sarawak River in the northwestern part of the island of Borneo. The limits of the City of Kuching include all that area in Kuching District containing an area approximately 431.01 square kilometres (166.41 sq mi) bounded from Gunung Lasak (Mount Lasak) in Muara Tebas to Batu Buaya (Crocodile Rock) in the Santubong peninsula following a series of survey marks as stated in the First Schedule of the City of Kuching Ordinance
column2: 1988. As a simplification of the legal statute
column3: the Kuching city limits extend from the Kuching International Airport in the south to the northern coast of the Santubong and Bako peninsulas; from the Kuching Wetlands National Park in the west to the Kuap River estuary in the east. The Sarawak River generally splits the city into North and South. The highest point in the city is Mount Santubong on the Santubong peninsula
column4: which is at 810.2 metres (2
column6: located 35 km north of the city centre. Rapid urbanisation has occurred in Greater Kuching and the urban sprawl extends to Penrissen

column15: Asajaya as well as Serian which is located about 65 km from Kuching.

column1: Kuching has a tropical rainforest climate (Köppen climate classification Af)
column2: moderately hot but very humid at times and receives substantial rainfall. The average annual rainfall is approximately 4
column3: 200 millimetres (170 in). Kuching is the wettest populated area (on average) in Malaysia with an average of 247 rainy days per year. Kuching receives only 5 hours of sunshine per day on average and an average of only 3.7 hours of sunshine per day in the month of January (wettest month of the year). The wettest times are during the North-East Monsoon months of November to February and the city's driest months are June through August. The temperature in Kuching ranges from 19 °C (66 °F) to 36 °C (97 °F) but the average temperature is around 23 °C (73 °F) in the early hours of the morning and rises to around 33 °C (91 °F) during mid afternoon but the heat index often reaches 42 °C (108 °F) during the "dry season" due to the humidity. This temperature stays almost constant throughout the year if it is not affected by the heavy rain and strong winds during the early hours of the morning which can bring the temperature down to 19 °C (66 °F)
column4: but this is very rare.

column1: Kuching International Airport (KCH) (ICAO Code : WBGG) is the main gateway for air passengers. The airport's history dates back to the 1940s and today the airport has undergoing many major redevelopment. The airport terminal is listed as the fourth busiest airport in Malaysia according to total passenger movements in 2013. Since 2009
column2: the airport has grown rapidly with an increasing number of passengers and aircraft movement. It is the secondary hub for Malaysia Airlines and AirAsia while became the third hub for MASWings
column3: which serves flights to smaller towns and rural areas in East Malaysia.

column21: and many more. More shopping malls are set to open in the city as construction continues. The Satok Weekend Market is located at Medan Niaga Satok and operated in Saturdays and Sundays. A varieties of vegetables and fruits can be found there including other handicrafts
column24: and a whole range of local snacks and delicacies.

column1: There are five cinemas located around the city
column2: most of them located inside shopping malls buildings (The Spring
column3: CityONE
column4: VivaCity
column6: Summer Mall). Most of the cinemas are owned by either Golden Screen Cinemas
column8: Lotus Five Star and TGV Cinemas. Bookaroo
column10: travelled from India to Kuching since 2016 and takes place in April on the city every year to featuring the Bookaroo Kuching Fest. The festival invites authors
column13: and performers from all over the world
column14: urging children to bring books with them.

column2: Kuching has been host to the Rainforest World Music Festival (RWMF)
column3: an annual music festival which brings performers and spectators to the region from all over the world. Hosted by the Sarawak Cultural Village near the Mount Santubong
column4: the festival is now one of the largest musical events in Malaysia. RWMF had been voted as Top 25 Best International Festivals by the British-based magazine Songlines.

column1: Music radio station set up in Sarawak is Radio Klasik FM (87.6)
column2: Nasional FM (88.1)
column3: Sarawak FM (88.9)
column4: TraXX FM (89.9)
column8: Hitz (95.3)

column1: Several countries have set up their consulates in Kuching
column2: including Australia
column3: Brunei
column4: China
column8: Poland and the United Kingdom.
